STRINGS: Afterwards, I was escorted by the First Division's officers
back to the police station.
After entering the lobby, I sluggishly headed underground.
Everybody who caught sight of me grimaced in shock.
I went down the stairs,
and opened the door to the detention center.
My destination was Sekimoto's cell.
"Those footsteps are... Houjou's, I see.
What is it?"
"Even though it's still early in the morning...
you're already awake, huh?"
"They put out the lights here early.
It's only natural that I wake up early also.
After all--"
I cut his explanation short.
"...What's wrong?
Why did you interrupt me?"
"I should be asking you that,
you're acting differently from normal."
"...We caught Blindman."
--Silence.
Despite it being great news to the ears of Soujirou Sekimoto, he
exhibited no behavior indicative of the delight he should be feeling.
"Why are you not saying anything?"
"...There's blood on you.
Are you all right? Any injuries?"
Checking the spot he pointed out,
I noticed blood had sullied my uniform.
It's not surprising he mistakenly thought I suffered
a grievous injury, considering the way the blood stuck to me.
"Please relax. It's not mine.
I just wanted to tell you the good news before anything else."
"...You're not a good liar, are you?"
I haven't told this to anybody else hitherto now.
This man has no eye for people.
Once again, Sekimoto fell silent.
He fixed a mute stare on me.
"Please don't hush up.
If you have something, anything you want to say, please do.
Just as always."
"I don't believe this is the resolution you desired.
I feel the same, but... this is especially the case for you, isn't it?"
He's reading me like an open book.
No... it's only natural.
You don't need to be a psychic to tell from my face
that I'm not satisfied by this conclusion.
"Why is your face so overcast?"
His tone was gentle and amicable.
A total shift from his regular self.
He was akin to a
"If you want, I can keep company with you for as long as you'd like.
Won't you tell me all the things
you're keeping locked deep in your chest?"
--Silence.
This time I'm the one upholding it.
He's gently encouraging me.
This trivial impetus provoked the black emotions that writhed within me
to almost violently spew out of my mouth.
I took deeper and deeper breaths.
To stop my feeling from running wild at least.
Sekimoto didn't try to press me.
I must have conveyed how painful they felt.
Once enough time passed, my emotions settled down,
and I slowly began speaking yet again.
"Mr. Kazamori died while capturing the suspect."
"...You must be lying, right?"
"Unfortunately, it's the truth...
He risked his life to solve this case--
to arrest Blindman."
"Is that so... I don't know what to say.
I'm sorry.
But, it's unfortunate what happened to him. Truly."
"I'm grateful for your consideration.
It's up to us to take up Mr. Kazamori's will.
I'm also obliged for your various contributions."
"It really was all thanks to you.
Thank you... very much."
I bowed to him.
I lowered my head as deeply as I could.
However, my body felt very heavy and I was unable to lift it back up.
Still, I somehow managed to straighten my posture
and promptly turned to leave.
"Hold on, Houjou.
Did that suspect of yours call himself Blindman?"
"No, we haven't confirmed that yet...
But considering the circumstances, I believe the likelihood is high."
"The trigger was some photos of rubberneckers that
crowded the crime scenes. No matter which picture,
there always was one man among the spectators."
"When we went to question him, something caught my eye,
and so we maintained a stakeout of his house."
"A few days later, the suspect made a scene in his home,
which led us to raid it and discover the brutalized bodies
of his family inside.
The suspect intended to make a run for it, but we caught him--"
"Mr. Kazamori got into a scuffle with the deranged suspect,
who bit into his neck, causing excessive bleeding.
...Which resulted in him dying in the line of duty."
"..I see, hrm."
He crossed his arms and fell into deep thought.
It seems something is bothering him.
"The situation has already become the subject of
the First Divison's investigative efforts.
Sorry, but there's no more reason for you to be involved--"
"This suspect was sighted among the crowd of gawkers
who came to sightsee each crime scene's inspection, correct?"
"Yeah. What's the issue?"
"Misuzu... why are you here?
Did you finish forensics work already?
How did it go?"
"I skipped work."
"You skipped...!?
What are you saying!?"
Hearing such unimaginable words coming from a devoted worker like her
bamboozled me.
"But the crime scene inspection is still going on, right!?
Hey, Misuzu, just what are you thinking?"
"At times, you can be surprisingly dense when it comes to
other people's feelings. It's quite simple.
She's acting this way because she's worried about your precariousness."
Misuzu nodded at his comment.
"There's no way I could focus on work when
my colleague is wasting away, is there?"
Without thinking, I stared at Misuzu in surprise.
I could sense that she was overflowing with anger.
'Did you have to divulge my worry like that?', perchance.
"Ah... sorry.
Thank you."
"No need for that.
Instead, if you're hurting, tell it to me straight.
All I want is you being honest with me."
Tears were almost brimming over in spite of myself.
However, I strenuously held them back.
I couldn't help but look down at the pain.
Despite my efforts, the overflowing teardrops
plunged to the floor, where they formed a tiny splotch.
"See, you're repressing yourself again.
How many times do I have to say it?
I just want you to be honest with your feelings--"
I suddenly put up the palm of my hand,
interrupting Misuzu's plea.
"I'm fine now, I'm fine."
Awkwardly wiping my eyes with the back of my hand,
I supplanted my emotions.
The turbulent emotions that were on the verge of flooding out
vanished so thoroughly that it amazed even me,
and in their place, a serene feeling encompassed my body.
But simultaneously,
the same indignation that led to this state of affairs arose
far more intensely than the sadness from the loss of my partner.
"Continue with what you were saying, please.
Let's go back on-topic."
"Yes, let's.
The suspect was touring the crime scenes, yes?"
"Yeah, he was. We can't be certain since he was in the background,
but he appeared to be smiling as he got a good view of the scene.
It was a vulgar, very hateable grin."
"Where is he now?
If he was arrested without warrant,
he should have become a flatmate of mine, no?"
"That would be... slightly troublesome."
"What do you mean?"
"He's in no condition to be thrown down here yet.
Furthermore, the First Division are hounding him to make good on
this precious chance in the interrogation room."
"Their squalling and his wails are
making a stir on the ground floor."
"What's... his condition right now?"
"He's in confusion due to a hallucinogenic condition,
and is suffering from an extreme degree of starvation.
He can barely hold a conversation.
Nothing that comes out of his mouth makes sense."
"'I was just hungry.
I have to take my pills.
I'll keep being fat without them.'"
Misuzu reenacted his statements without interest or inflection.
Their childishness horribly mismatched Misuzu's coolness.
"'That drug's the greatest.
You don't feel your empty stomach when you take them.'"
"'You can slim down as much as you want.
You can slim down even if you eat terribly.'"
"'If I don't get slim, she won't recognize me.'"
"'--Eh, who is she?
That's obvious.
Haruka Minase. My Haruka.'"
"Haruka Minase... So, did he say anything else about her?"
"No idea. I wasn't there.
It's just something I heard while pretending to work."
Misuzu took a short breath, 'phew'.
"--That's the update.
Are you satisfied, Mr. Soujirou Sekimoto?"
He crossed his arms and began to ponder.
The look on his face gave me the impression he wasn't convinced.
"...Hey, what are you thinking about?"
My inquiry went unanswered.
He kept thinking in silence for a while.
But this silence was plainly different from before.
Thoughts seemed to swirl inside his head at terrific speeds.
"...As is, the best verdict you can expect is not guilty
by reason of insanity. You need to find conclusive evidence
as soon as possible before some imprudent human rights attorney
sniffs this out and wrests him away from you."
"But it's a fact that he committed murder.
He can't possibly be acquitted so easily.
Moreover, why a human rights attorney...?"
"Their information network is remarkable.
If there is even the slightest doubt about the charges,
they will pull out all the stops to gain an acquittal.
One got in contact with myself as well, in fact."
"He said he'd grant me my freedom in exchange for a hefty price.
But he didn't mind if I hadn't the money.
As long as I wrote a prison diary, of course."
"Like a hyena, huh."
"Now then, there naturally also are attorneys with good intentions.
But lamentably, I never made acquaintance with any of those people."
"To that lot, releasing arrestees into the wild is no big deal.
These people would bring you to a hospital under the
pretext of medical treatment just to make up a cause
for a state indemnity lawsuit."
"Until his trial finishes,
your suspect will be able to walk free."
Kanaya, Mr. Kazamori's murderer, will be able to walk free...!?
That's ridiculous.
He must pay for his sins. He has to.
"By the way, forensics should be at the suspect's house
at the moment, since the First Division's initial response team
reported that they discovered drugs there.
They're establishing whether they were his property."
"--Misuzu. I'm sorry,
but could you step outside for a bit?"
"Eh? That's fine by me, but...
what's the matter?"
"I want to talk. With him."
Alright, Misuzu curtly answered,
before leaving the room as I requested.
After she left, I stayed quiet for a minute.
From where should I start?
I took my time to organize my feelings on the matter.
He patiently awaited me to break the ice as well.
"You told me to be honest."
"Indeed."
"However, I don't understand what's being honest and what isn't."
"Since long, or rather, forever ago,
when I lost my cool, I would charge head-in first
and ask questions later."
"I can understand that.
It happens to everybody."
"But, because of my weakness, Mr. Kazamori was...!"
"There is no man strong enough to
shoulder all responsibility by himself."
"But we can't not take responsibility. That's why when I, I...
I got scared of that grotesque man, and my body froze up--
If I had the slightest bit more courage,
Mr. Kazamori wouldn't have had to die...!"
"Then what? Do you want to be told you aren't at fault?"
"We don't have the time for worthless self-vindication.
You, especially, should know that, no?"
"Pardon me, but I have no plans to fake camaraderie with you."
"Kazamori is dead, you are alive.
Those are the facts.
Thus, you who lived still has ability to act."
"Stand on your feet. Stand up and brave reality.
Even if you must cheer the self you abhor,
plunge into the depths of this case."
"Otherwise, these incidents most likely won't ever end."
"I doubt they'll grasp even a shred of the truth."
"These incidents won't end...!?"
I stared, bug-eyed, in confusion.
Sekimoto's stare back was deadly serious.
Those by no means were the eyes of a liar.
but I could only find such a sudden declaration dubious.
"Listen, the case still hasn't revealed its full picture.
Confront the woman brought up earlier, Haruka Minase.
I'm sure she will serve as the lead you need."
"...If you don't, even more people will die."
"How can you be so certain?
What's the basis for that claim?"
"Has the suspect affirmed if he was Blindman yet?"
"No. I see where you're coming from,
but considering the condition we found him in..."
"I'd throw even that into question.
The suspect murdered his family, yes,
but did he gouge out their eyes?"
"Ah... S-still,
the possibility that he wasn't thinking properly still remains."
"Remember, Blindman began as a fictional existence.
The people who know that in the world are overwhelmingly few."
"Despite that, why did these incidents,
modeled after that story, occur in this town?"
"That's because the culprit knows a lot
about Blindman and its origins..."
"That's right. Which is presicely why I suspected my pupil,
Takenaka, who disappeared right under my nose..."
"But that suspicion was disproven when
he himself was killed by Blindman."
"I don't know why Blindman kills people.
And I'm afraid because of that lack of knowledge.
After all, while I was creating it, I purposely left it vague."
"However, I've caught a glimpse of a motive
from the murder that the suspect you arrested committed."
"Doesn't family or money troubles seem like
cheap, easily seen-through motives to you?"
"What's more, he was delirious due to medicine or whatever.
Blindman absolutely did not have such humanly reasons
for acting the way it does."
Now that he mentions it, that's definitely the case.
Kanaya is unemployed and hardly has a good relationship with his family.
And throughout the various serial murders,
their motive for killing has always been unclear.
"Listen, Houjou, I won't deny the likelihood of
the suspect you apprehended this time knowing something."
"And it would be unnatural for an unconnected grotesque murder case
to happen concurrently to a serial killer case."
"However, it intrinsically differs in character from Blindman."
Certainly.
If his reasoning is correct,
much of this case is still buried in darkness.
"The name raised earlier-- I think it was..."
"Haruka Minase."
"Yes, I'll review the situation with Ms. Haruka Minase another time.
I can trust your intuition, can't I?"
"That is up to you to decide.
However-- even if it feels wrong to lecture a detective about this--
investigating the peripheral relationships of suspects
is the most basic of basics."
"Yeah. That's true.
I can't believe I had to have you tell me that."
"You can think of it as rent for letting me reside here.
One more thing, Houjou, and take at least this to heart."
"If you can't keep ahold of yourself, it'll be all over.
Squarely because you're part of an unit removed from the
regular police organization, the Specialized Patrol Division."
"After all, it would be unthinkable for an investigative unit
to use a groundless rumor as a pointer.
For you see, I have no proof or anything to back me up."
"Still, there is no doubt that a person who studied Blindman
to a fine point and could loyally mimic its actions
yet lurks in this town."
"That person probably is chuckling to themselves at
the lasting chaos and the investigation's lack of results.
But none other than you may be able to reach them."
"...I see."
"Don't let Kazamori's death be in vain.
I myself liked him, even if he had a foul mouth.
If I could, I'd like to hear his abusive language again."
Sekimoto's own way of expressing his frustration
elicited a faint, bitter smile from me.
I still have things I must do.
And Mr. Kazamori's mourning period hasn't ended either.
Thus, as the one left behind,
I can only carry out his dying wishes.
